For example, it won't be easy to do a side business, work as a volunteer developer, be on a leadership position in communities etc. Basically anything where you're getting any sort of compenstation or are managing something is highly regulated- Many regulations apply to your dependents and people you are living with. For example, you'll need to disclose statements of your dependents, and even they cannot be doing short term trading (buying and selling the same stock within 30 days)GS is a bank, so:- usually not so great in handing out money. For example, no free food, the wfh allowance is lesser compared to other companies.- Has been very eager to call people back to office. I have heard of no remote-only positionsIn addition:- In GS, you work on an NDS. This means your actual system is hosted in NYC, while sitting in your office you do a remote login. It's essentially teamviewer, just slightly better. But you can imagine how annoying the lag on the system can become. I have become habituated. - some teams have terrible WLB because of time zones.- some teams are saturated. Description: Not the firm it used to be
Pros: GS is still a blue-chip firm functioning primarily as a training ground for smart, talented graduates. It's possible, with fantastic people skills and a bit of luck, to develop your career here across functional areas and the name does hold weight in the finance industry. In a nutshell, it can be a good springboard to a better job elsewhere.
Cons: The firm is in terminal decline. It may be doing better financially than it almost ever has, but its unwavering focus on strategic locations and underpaying individuals has done tremendous damage to the quality of its people and its services, even during a period as short as the past four years I've worked there. GS prides itself on paying its employees less than market - either by encouraging internal mobility from its back to its front office and then never catching those individuals up to their peers (i.e., cheap labor for higher value work), by hiring new engineers almost exclusively in SLC, Dallas, and Bangalore, or by raising salaries for new analysts (as happened earlier this year) and then not adjusting salaries for earlier analyst classes, thereby causing ire among thousands of hires who have stuck around to keep the firm running. Also, its name is no longer the silver bullet in recruiting that it used to be. The market is well aware that the GS mystique is more or less gone, and this is just another investment bank like Citi or JPMorgan Chase, so don't count on good job offers to flow your way after a few years unless you are in IBD or certain groups in GMD/AMD. The amount of internal politics to get ahead and get compensated as you think you should at a place like GS is extraordinary - your MD holds all the cards for your career, and if he or she is not invested in you, then you are simply wasting your time as another GS drone. I haven't even touched on the level of bureaucracy, often enforced by absolutely miserable individuals in Compliance and CWS in Bangalore and SLC who I secretly think enjoy blocking and frustrating the front office individuals wherever possible.

Pros: - One good thing about GS is that you definitely can take ownership of a lot of things if you want to. It's generally not too hard to take on more responsibility if you prove yourself. Cons: - Unfortunately, the compensation is on the lower side. Your yearly cash bonus is a big part of your compensation, and there's no real way to know how much it will be. You can get exceeds ratings and still get no raise. You could get meets ratings and get more bonus than your buddy who got exceeds on another team. It's all really variable. The total compensation of salary + bonus also unfortunately isn't very competitive with tech companies which tend to pay better on salary alone and have better work life balance and benefits.- It's easy to feel like a second class citizen if you are a Software Engineer. - Poor work-life-balance on some teams.- It can be hard to work with the latest technologies due to all the legal and compliance issues that have to be resolved first.
